module.title: Operations
module.description: Airport operations, emergency procedures, crew resource management, aeronautical decision making, physiology, and maintenance

lessons.title: Radio Communications
objectives: Understand the difference between towered and non-towered airport communications
Identify CTAF, UNICOM, and ATIS and their purposes
Recite the phonetic alphabet and aviation number pronunciations
Interpret standard radio phraseology for altitudes, directions, and time

sections.title: Why Radio Knowledge Matters
sections.content:
## Why Remote Pilots Need Radio Knowledge

Although Part 107 does not require remote pilots to communicate with ATC by radio, the FAA expects you to understand aviation radio procedures.

**Why?** Monitoring radio frequencies gives you critical situational awareness about manned aircraft near your operating area.

## Towered vs. Non-Towered Airports

| Airport Type | Sectional Chart Color | Description |
|---|---|---|
| Towered | **Blue** | Active ATC tower manages operations |
| Non-towered | **Magenta** | Pilots self-coordinate |

### What This Means for Remote Pilots

When operating near any airport, you should **monitor** the appropriate frequency to maintain awareness of manned aircraft. You should rarely transmit unless facing a genuine emergency.

**Your primary tool is listening.**

sections.title: CTAF - Common Traffic Advisory Frequency
sections.content:
## What is CTAF?

**CTAF** (Common Traffic Advisory Frequency) is the frequency where pilots announce their position and intentions at and around airports. It is the primary frequency for pilot-to-pilot communication at non-towered airports.

## Finding CTAF on a Sectional Chart

Look for the circled "C" symbol next to the airport data. The frequency appears before the circle-C notation.

At towered airports, the CTAF is typically the tower frequency.

## Default CTAF

When no CTAF is published, the default frequency is **122.9 MHz**.

## Remote Pilot Use

Monitor CTAF on an aviation handheld radio to hear manned aircraft announcements about their:
- Position
- Runway in use
- Intentions

This tells you where traffic is and when to expect aircraft nearby.

bogeyman.message: Remote pilots should MONITOR radio frequencies, not transmit. You're listening for situational awareness, not participating in traffic coordination (unless there's a genuine emergency).

sections.title: UNICOM and ATIS
sections.content:
## UNICOM

UNICOM (Universal Communications) is a ground-based advisory station at airports — typically operated by a private agency (an FBO or airport operator), not by ATC.

### Services UNICOM Provides
- Weather conditions
- Wind direction
- Recommended runway
- Fuel availability
- Parking information

### Common UNICOM Frequency
**122.8 MHz** (but varies by airport — always check)

## Key Distinction: CTAF vs. UNICOM

| Service | Purpose |
|---|---|
| CTAF | Pilot-to-pilot frequency for traffic coordination |
| UNICOM | Ground station providing advisory information |

## ATIS - Automatic Terminal Information Service

ATIS is a continuously broadcast recorded message at busier airports providing:
- Current weather
- Active runway
- Wind, visibility, altimeter setting
- NOTAMs and approach information

### Phonetic Identifiers

Each ATIS update receives a sequential letter:
- First of the day: "Information Alpha"
- Next update: "Information Bravo"
- Continues through Zulu, then cycles back to Alpha

bogeyman.message: Don't confuse UNICOM (122.8) with the default CTAF (122.9). They are DIFFERENT services on DIFFERENT frequencies. This is a common exam trap!

sections.title: The Phonetic Alphabet
sections.content:
## The NATO/ICAO Phonetic Alphabet

The phonetic alphabet eliminates confusion in radio communication. **Memorize all 26 code words.**

| A – Alfa | B – Bravo | C – Charlie | D – Delta |
|---|---|---|---|
| E – Echo | F – Foxtrot | G – Golf | H – Hotel |
| I – India | J – Juliett | K – Kilo | L – Lima |
| M – Mike | N – November | O – Oscar | P – Papa |
| Q – Quebec | R – Romeo | S – Sierra | T – Tango |
| U – Uniform | V – Victor | W – Whiskey | X – X-ray |
| Y – Yankee | Z – Zulu | | |

## Number Pronunciation in Aviation

| Number | Pronunciation |
|---|---|
| 0 | "Zero" (not "oh") |
| 3 | "Tree" (not "three") |
| 5 | "Fife" (not "five") |
| 9 | "Niner" (not "nine") |

## Spelling Notes

Note the spellings:
- **Alfa** (not Alpha)
- **Juliett** (with double-t)

bogeyman.message: The FAA tests specific number pronunciations: TREE (3), FIFE (5), and NINER (9). Also note the spellings: ALFA (not Alpha) and JULIETT (double-t).

sections.title: Radio Phraseology
sections.content:
## Altitudes (below 18,000 feet)

Stated as separate digits of the thousands plus hundreds:
- 1,500 feet = "One thousand five hundred"
- 10,500 feet = "One zero thousand five hundred"
- Flight Level 250 (at/above 18,000 ft) = "Flight level two five zero"

## Directions

Aviation radio communications use **magnetic headings**, not true headings.

## Speed

Aviation uses **knots** (nautical miles per hour), not miles per hour.

## Time

All aviation times are stated in **UTC (Zulu time)**, using the 24-hour clock.

- 2:30 PM local (EST) = 1930Z (Zulu)
- Written as 1930Z or 19:30 UTC

## Self-Announce Format

**Standard format:**
"[Airport name] traffic, [aircraft type and N-number], [position], [altitude], [intentions], [airport name]"

**Example:**
"Riverside traffic, Cessna Four Seven Six Five Juliet, 10 miles south, 2,000 feet, inbound for landing runway 27, Riverside."

bogeyman.message: If a question mentions 'Zulu time' or 'UTC,' remember it's the same thing — Universal Coordinated Time at the Prime Meridian.

sections.title: Traffic Pattern Calls
sections.content:
## Understanding Traffic Pattern Calls

Manned aircraft pilots announce their position at key points. Understanding these calls helps you know where aircraft are.

## Traffic Pattern Position Calls You'll Hear

- **"Entering downwind runway 27"** — aircraft is flying parallel to the runway, opposite direction of landing
- **"Turning base runway 27"** — aircraft is making the turn toward the runway
- **"Final runway 27"** — aircraft is on final approach, about to land
- **"Departing runway 27 to the north"** — aircraft has taken off and is leaving the area

## The Five Traffic Pattern Legs (in order)

1. **Upwind** — climbing along the runway heading after takeoff
2. **Crosswind** — 90° turn from upwind, still climbing
3. **Downwind** — parallel to the runway in the opposite direction (the longest leg)
4. **Base** — 90° turn toward the runway, descending
5. **Final** — aligned with the runway, on approach to land

## Aircraft Call Signs

U.S. aircraft are identified by **N-numbers** — registration numbers beginning with "N" followed by up to 5 alphanumeric characters (e.g., N978CP, N1234).

On the radio, civil aircraft pilots use the manufacturer name plus the registration number:
"Cessna Four Seven Six Five Juliet" (not "November Four Seven Six Five Juliet")

bogeyman.message: Know the five traffic pattern legs IN ORDER: upwind, crosswind, downwind, base, final. The FAA tests whether you can interpret these radio calls!

lessons.title: Airport Operations
objectives: Identify airport types by sectional chart color
Interpret runway markings and airport signs
Understand traffic patterns and standard pattern altitude
Recognize airport lighting systems

sections.title: Types of Airports
sections.content:
## Airport Types on Sectional Charts

| Airport Type | Sectional Chart Color | Description |
|---|---|---|
| Towered | **Blue** | Active ATC control tower |
| Non-towered | **Magenta** | No active tower; pilots self-coordinate |
| Heliport | Special "H" symbol | Designated rotorcraft landing area |
| Seaplane base | Special symbol | Water-based operations |

## ATC Tower Frequencies

At a towered airport, multiple frequencies handle different functions:

| Frequency | Function |
|---|---|
| Clearance Delivery | Route clearances before taxi |
| Ground Control | Taxiway and surface movement |
| Tower | Runway operations, takeoff/landing clearances |
| Approach/Departure | Radar-based arrival/departure sequencing |

## Remote Pilot Considerations

Remote pilots can monitor these frequencies for situational awareness but should not transmit unless facing a genuine emergency.

bogeyman.message: Blue = towered, magenta = non-towered. This is HEAVILY tested on the exam!

sections.title: Runway Markings
sections.content:
## Runway Numbering

The runway number is the **magnetic heading divided by 10** and rounded.

- A runway oriented 270° magnetic is **Runway 27**
- The opposite end is **Runway 09** (180° difference)

## Color Rules

- **White** markings = on the runway
- **Yellow** markings = on taxiways and non-runway areas
- **Yellow chevrons** = blast pad (not for taxiing, takeoff, or landing)

## Displaced Threshold

White arrows along the centerline lead to a threshold bar set back from the physical runway end.

- Landing aircraft must touch down **beyond** the displaced threshold
- The area before it **can** be used for takeoff and rollout

## Key Markings

| Marking | Description |
|---|---|
| Threshold markings | White stripes at beginning of landing portion |
| Centerline | White dashed line down the middle |
| Touchdown zone | Groups of stripes on each side of centerline |
| Hold short lines | Four yellow lines (two solid, two dashed) |

sections.title: Airport Signs
sections.content:
## Airport Sign Color Code

Know the color code — this is heavily tested:

| Sign Type | Colors | Purpose |
|---|---|---|
| **Mandatory** | White on **red** background | STOP, hold short, no entry |
| **Location** | Black on **yellow** background | Identifies where you are |
| **Directional** | Yellow on **black** background | Points to where you're going |

## Memory Aid

- **R**ed = **R**equired to comply (mandatory)
- **Y**ellow background = **Y**ou are here (location)
- **B**lack background = **B**earing/direction

bogeyman.message: The sign color coding is HEAVILY tested. RED background = MANDATORY (must comply). Yellow background = location (you are here). Black background = directional (where you're going).

sections.title: Traffic Patterns
sections.content:
## Standard Traffic Pattern

The standard traffic pattern is a **left-hand rectangular pattern** with five legs:

1. **Upwind** — climbing along the runway heading after takeoff
2. **Crosswind** — 90° turn from upwind, still climbing
3. **Downwind** — parallel to the runway in the opposite direction (the longest leg)
4. **Base** — 90° turn toward the runway, descending
5. **Final** — aligned with the runway, on approach to land

## Standard Pattern Altitude

**1,000 feet AGL** for propeller-driven aircraft.

## Right-Hand Patterns

Some airports use right-hand traffic due to terrain, noise, or other factors. Check the Chart Supplement or look for the traffic pattern indicator on the segmented circle.

## Segmented Circle

A visual indicator system at non-towered airports:
- L-shaped extensions show traffic pattern direction
- Wind cone indicates current wind direction

## Why This Matters for UAS

- Aircraft on approach/departure are at **low altitude** — conflict risk is highest
- Traffic pattern altitude (1,000 AGL) overlaps with the Part 107 400-foot ceiling
- Watch for aircraft in the pattern when operating near airports

bogeyman.message: Traffic pattern questions are common. Standard pattern is LEFT turns at 1,000 AGL. Don't confuse the order: downwind comes BEFORE base, not after!

sections.title: Airport Lighting
sections.content:
## Runway Edge Lights

White along the length; **yellow for the last 2,000 feet** (caution zone before runway end).

## Visual Glide Slope Indicators

**VASI/PAPI** provide descent guidance using red/white light patterns:
- Both give a standard **3-degree glide path**
- PAPI uses four light boxes on the left side of the runway

## Rotating Beacons

| Airport Type | Beacon Pattern |
|---|---|
| Civilian airport | Alternating **white and green** |
| Military airport | Two quick white flashes then green (white-white-green) |

## Pilot-Controlled Lighting (PCL)

At non-towered airports, pilots activate runway lights via microphone clicks:
- **7 clicks** = highest intensity
- **5 clicks** = medium
- **3 clicks** = low

## Sources for Airport Data

| Source | Information Provided |
|---|---|
| Sectional Charts | Airport location, type, runway configuration, frequencies, airspace |
| Chart Supplements (A/FD) | Detailed info: runway dimensions, surface, fuel, lighting, hours |

bogeyman.message: Runway edge lights are NOT all white — the last 2,000 feet are YELLOW. Also: civilian beacon = white/green; military = white-white-green.

sections.title: Bird and Wildlife Hazards
sections.content:
## Bird Strike Risk

Bird strikes are a significant aviation hazard:
- Over **90% occur at or below 3,000 feet AGL**
- Migratory birds (geese, ducks) can be found up to 7,000 feet during migration

## Migration Seasons

- **Spring:** March–April
- **Fall:** August–November

## Reporting Bird Strikes

Use **FAA Form 5200-7** (Bird/Other Wildlife Strike Report). Anyone with knowledge of a strike is encouraged to report.

## Security Identification Display Areas (SIDA)

SIDA is a restricted security zone at airports regulated under TSA rules.

**Why it matters for drone pilots:**
- Operating in or near SIDA areas requires authorization
- Flying drones into SIDA without authorization violates airport security

bogeyman.message: Know the migration seasons: spring (March-April) and fall (August-November). Birds can be at HIGH altitudes during migration!

lessons.title: Emergency Procedures
objectives: Explain emergency planning and PIC emergency authority
Describe lithium battery hazards and proper fire response
Understand loss of control link and GPS procedures
Identify procedures for operations over people and at night

sections.title: Emergency Planning
sections.content:
## Pre-Flight Emergency Briefing

**Before every flight**, the remote PIC must brief all personnel on emergency procedures (14 CFR 107.49).

Everyone involved must know:
- Their roles
- What to do if something goes wrong
- Communication protocols

## Emergency Authority (14 CFR 107.21)

In a genuine in-flight emergency requiring immediate action, the remote PIC may deviate from **any** Part 107 rule to the extent necessary to meet the emergency.

This is your ultimate safety valve — but it applies only to real emergencies, not convenience.

## When to Invoke Emergency Authority

- Search and rescue operations
- Fire suppression support
- Imminent risk to persons on the ground
- Any situation where following the rules would create greater danger

bogeyman.message: The pre-flight briefing on emergency procedures is MANDATORY for all crew. The remote PIC has authority to deviate from ANY rule during a genuine emergency.

sections.title: Lithium Battery Hazards
sections.content:
## Safe Battery Practices

This is one of the most testable topics in Section V.

### Safe Transportation
- Inspect batteries for swelling, cracks, or damage
- Protect terminals from short circuits (use caps or tape)
- Transport in protective cases or fireproof bags
- For air transport: discharge to **below 30%** state of charge

### Safe Charging
- Always use the manufacturer-recommended charger
- **Never leave batteries charging unattended**
- Charge on a non-flammable surface with ventilation
- Stop charging immediately if battery becomes hot or swells
- Never overcharge

### Safe Usage
- Don't over-discharge (land with 20%+ remaining)
- Inspect before every flight — swollen batteries must not be flown
- Store at **40–60% charge** for long-term storage
- Store at room temperature (68–77°F / 20–25°C)

sections.title: Thermal Runaway and Fire Response
sections.content:
## What is Thermal Runaway?

**Thermal runaway** is a self-accelerating chemical reaction that produces:
- Extreme heat (750°F+)
- Toxic smoke
- Flames

Once it starts, it cannot be easily stopped.

## Causes of Thermal Runaway

- Overcharging
- Physical damage (crush/puncture)
- Manufacturing defects
- Short circuits
- Over-discharge followed by fast recharge

## Fire Response — What to Use

| Method | Effective? |
|---|---|
| **Dry powder (Class D) fire extinguisher** | **YES** — primary method |
| **Dry sand or salt** | **YES** — smothers the fire |
| **Let it burn in open area** | **YES** — if safe, let it burn out |
| Water | **NO** — lithium reacts with water |
| Standard foam extinguisher | **NO** — ineffective |
| CO₂ extinguisher | **NO** — ineffective |

## State of Charge and Fire Risk

**High state of charge = higher fire risk.**

Batteries at 70–100% charge produce significantly more violent thermal runaway compared to batteries at 30%. This is why the FAA requires batteries to be discharged below 30% for air transport.

bogeyman.message: The FAA loves testing what NOT to use on a lithium fire. NEVER use water, foam, or CO₂. Use dry powder (Class D) or sand!

sections.title: Loss of Control Link
sections.content:
## When Control Link is Lost

When the radio link between your controller and the drone is lost, you can no longer send commands. The primary safety feature is **Return-to-Home (RTH)**.

## How RTH Works

1. The aircraft automatically climbs to a pre-set safety altitude
2. Navigates back to its takeoff point using GPS
3. Descends and lands at the home point

## Critical Limitation: RTH Depends on GPS

If GPS is unavailable or unreliable (urban canyons, indoor, interference), **RTH may fail**.

A failed RTH with a lost control link can result in a **fly-away** — the drone drifts uncontrolled.

## Prevention

- Verify GPS lock before launch (typically 8+ satellites)
- Pre-program RTH altitude above surrounding obstacles
- Test RTH on the ground before mission
- Maintain visual line of sight
- Monitor signal strength throughout flight

bogeyman.message: RTH is NOT foolproof. It depends ENTIRELY on GPS. If GPS is lost or degraded, RTH will fail. This is a favorite exam topic!

sections.title: Loss of GPS Signal
sections.content:
## What Happens When GPS is Lost

When GPS is lost, the drone switches to **ATTI (Attitude) mode**:

| Function | Status |
|---|---|
| Altitude hold | **Maintained** (barometer keeps altitude) |
| Position hold | **Lost** (drone drifts with the wind) |
| Pilot control | **Required** to prevent drift |

## Key Point

The drone does NOT fall from the sky — it stays at altitude but moves with the wind.

## How to Respond

1. Maintain visual contact
2. Use manual stick inputs to counteract drift
3. Land as soon as safely possible

## GPS Loss vs. Control Link Loss

| Failure | Result |
|---|---|
| GPS loss | Position drift (pilot still has control) |
| Control link loss | No commands can be sent (RTH activates) |

They are different failures requiring different responses.

bogeyman.message: GPS loss ≠ altitude loss. The barometer maintains altitude. The key issue is POSITION DRIFT, requiring constant pilot input to counteract wind.

sections.title: Operations Over People and at Night
sections.content:
## Operations Over People

If a non-participant enters your flight area during operations:
- **Land the aircraft**, OR
- **Move it away** from the person

Do not continue flying over non-participants unless your operation qualifies under Part 107 Subpart D (Categories 1–4) and all requirements are met.

If an emergency requires flight over people (search and rescue, fire suppression), the remote PIC may invoke emergency authority under 14 CFR 107.21.

## Night Operations Challenges

Night operations present unique challenges:
- Loss of visual references
- Spatial disorientation
- Difficulty judging distance and altitude

## If You Lose Visual Contact at Night

1. **Command the aircraft to hover/hold position** immediately
2. **Stop all movement** until visual contact is re-established
3. If you cannot re-establish visual contact, initiate descent to a known safe altitude or land

## Frequency Spectrums

Most consumer drones operate on unlicensed ISM bands:

| Band | Congestion | Range |
|---|---|---|
| 2.4 GHz | High (shared with Wi-Fi, Bluetooth) | Longer |
| 5.8 GHz | Lower | Shorter |

**Sources of interference:** Wi-Fi access points, Bluetooth devices, microwave ovens, power lines, metal buildings, cell towers.

lessons.title: Aeronautical Decision-Making
objectives: Apply the DECIDE model to flight situations
Identify the five hazardous attitudes and their antidotes
Use IMSAFE and PAVE checklists for risk assessment
Understand crew resource management principles

sections.title: What is ADM?
sections.content:
## Aeronautical Decision-Making

ADM is a systematic approach to risk assessment and decision-making during flight operations.

**Key Fact:** Approximately 80% of aviation accidents involve human error — ADM is designed to break the accident chain.

## The DECIDE Model (Six Steps)

1. **D**etect the change or problem
2. **E**stimate the need to react (how urgent is it?)
3. **C**hoose a desired outcome
4. **I**dentify actions that could achieve that outcome
5. **D**o the necessary action
6. **E**valuate the effect of the action

This is a continuous loop — after evaluating, you detect again. Decision-making never stops during a flight.

## The 3P Model

1. **Perceive** hazards (using the PAVE checklist)
2. **Process** the level of risk (assess severity and probability)
3. **Perform** risk mitigation (take action to reduce risk)

bogeyman.message: Questions often present a scenario and ask which DECIDE step is being demonstrated. Know the sequence: Detect, Estimate, Choose, Identify, Do, Evaluate.

sections.title: The Five Hazardous Attitudes
sections.content:
## The Five Hazardous Attitudes

**This is one of the most heavily tested topics on the entire exam.** Memorize all five attitudes and their antidotes.

| Attitude | Characteristic | Antidote |
|---|---|---|
| **Anti-authority** | "Don't tell me what to do" | "Follow the rules — they are usually right" |
| **Impulsivity** | "Do it quickly!" | "Not so fast — think first" |
| **Invulnerability** | "It won't happen to me" | "It could happen to me" |
| **Macho** | "I can do it — watch this" | "Taking chances is foolish" |
| **Resignation** | "What's the use?" | "I'm not helpless — I can make a difference" |

## How to Identify Each in Exam Scenarios

- **Anti-authority:** Pilot ignores rules, skips checklists, disregards NOTAMs
- **Impulsivity:** Pilot rushes decisions under time pressure, skips preflight
- **Invulnerability:** Pilot flies in marginal weather because "I've done it before"
- **Macho:** Pilot takes unnecessary risks to impress a client
- **Resignation:** VO sees hazard but doesn't say anything because "the PIC already decided"

bogeyman.message: MEMORIZE the five hazardous attitudes and their antidotes. Read scenario questions carefully — identify the attitude BEFORE looking at answer choices!

sections.title: The IMSAFE Checklist
sections.content:
## Personal Fitness Assessment

Before every flight, assess yourself using IMSAFE:

| Letter | Factor | Question to Ask |
|---|---|---|
| **I** | Illness | Am I sick or feeling unwell? |
| **M** | Medication | Am I taking anything that could impair me? |
| **S** | Stress | Am I under unusual stress? |
| **A** | Alcohol | Have I had alcohol in the last 8 hours? Is my BAC below 0.04%? |
| **F** | Fatigue | Am I well-rested? |
| **E** | Emotion | Am I emotionally fit to make good decisions? |

## Honest Self-Assessment

The key is honesty. Rationalizations like:
- "I'll be fine once we start"
- "It's only mild stress"

...are exactly the kind of thinking that leads to accidents.

If any factor is negative, either **mitigate the issue** or **do not fly**.

sections.title: The PAVE Checklist
sections.content:
## Operational Risk Assessment

Evaluate four risk categories before the mission:

| Letter | Factor | What to Assess |
|---|---|---|
| **P** | Pilot | Use IMSAFE; also consider currency and experience |
| **A** | Aircraft | Condition, maintenance status, battery health, payload |
| **V** | enVironment | Weather, terrain, airspace, EMI, time of day |
| **E** | External pressures | Client pressure, time constraints, financial incentives |

## External Pressures — The "E" Factor

External pressures include:
- Client demands ("Fly NOW or we won't pay")
- Time constraints
- Financial pressure
- Peer pressure

**The correct response:** Never let pressure override safety.

bogeyman.message: The FAA expects you to recognize when EXTERNAL PRESSURE is driving a poor decision. 'The client says fly NOW or they won't pay' is textbook external pressure — safety comes first!

sections.title: Crew Resource Management
sections.content:
## What is CRM?

CRM is the effective coordination, communication, and decision-making among all team members.

## Key Principles for sUAS

- Use standard, clear phraseology
  - Good: "Aircraft sighted, 2 o'clock, 500 feet, moving toward us"
  - Bad: "Plane nearby"
- **Cross-monitor** — crew members watch each other's actions
- Create a culture where anyone can raise safety concerns

## Common CRM Failures

| Failure | Hazardous Attitude |
|---|---|
| VO not speaking up about a hazard | Resignation |
| PIC dismissing valid crew concerns | Anti-authority |
| Unclear role assignments | Poor communication |

## Effective Team Communication

**Pre-flight briefing is mandatory.** Before every flight, the PIC must brief all personnel on:
- Mission plan
- Roles
- Emergency procedures
- Communication protocols

**During flight:** The VO continuously provides situational updates. The PIC maintains control and makes safety decisions.

**The Remote PIC has final authority** over all decisions, but effective CRM means taking crew input seriously.

sections.title: Situational Awareness
sections.content:
## What is Situational Awareness?

Situational awareness (SA) is your understanding of:
1. **What's happening** around you
2. **What it means** for safety
3. **What's going to happen next** if you don't act

## Three Levels of SA

1. **Perception** — What is happening right now?
2. **Comprehension** — What does it mean for safety?
3. **Projection** — What will happen next if I don't act?

## Common Causes of SA Loss

| Cause | Example |
|---|---|
| Tunneling/fixation | Troubleshooting GPS while ignoring approaching aircraft |
| Workload overload | Too many tasks competing for attention |
| Fatigue and stress | Reduced cognitive capacity |
| False assumptions | Assuming weather won't change |

## Task Management Priority

1. **Aviate** — Control the aircraft first
2. **Navigate** — Know where you are
3. **Communicate** — Tell others what's happening

bogeyman.message: If a question describes a pilot focused on one problem while ignoring everything else, the answer is 'loss of situational awareness' or 'fixation.'

lessons.title: Physiology
objectives: State the alcohol and drug rules for remote pilots
Identify medications that affect fitness for flight
Explain physiological factors affecting vision and night operations
Describe stress, fatigue, and hyperventilation effects

sections.title: Alcohol and Drug Rules
sections.content:
## The Rules (14 CFR 107.27)

| Rule | Requirement |
|---|---|
| "Bottle to throttle" | No alcohol within **8 hours** before acting as PIC, VO, or crew |
| BAC limit | Blood alcohol must be below **0.04%** |
| Both conditions | **BOTH** the 8-hour rule AND the BAC limit must be met |
| Under the influence | Cannot operate while under the influence of any drug that impairs safety |

## Critical Point: BOTH Requirements

Waiting 8 hours is **not enough** if your BAC is still at or above 0.04%.

**Both conditions must be satisfied.**

## Example

A pilot had two beers at 7:00 PM. At 4:00 AM (9 hours later), BAC is 0.02%.

**Can they fly?** Yes — more than 8 hours have passed AND BAC is below 0.04%.

However, the pilot should still honestly self-assess whether they feel any residual effects.

bogeyman.message: The FAA tests the BOTH requirement. 8 hours is not enough if BAC ≥ 0.04%. And BAC < 0.04% is not enough if less than 8 hours have passed. BOTH conditions must be met!

sections.title: Medication
sections.content:
## Self-Assessment Requirement

Part 107 does not require an FAA medical certificate, but the remote PIC must self-assess whether any medication impairs their ability to fly safely.

## Sedating Medications (NOT Acceptable)

First-generation antihistamines like **diphenhydramine (Benadryl)** cause significant drowsiness and impair judgment.

Even some second-generation antihistamines like **cetirizine (Zyrtec)** can cause drowsiness in some individuals.

## Potentially Acceptable Medications

Non-sedating antihistamines:
- **Loratadine (Claritin)**
- **Fexofenadine (Allegra)**

Provided the pilot verifies no adverse effects on their performance.

## Decision Guide

| Medication | Can You Fly? |
|---|---|
| Benadryl (diphenhydramine) | **No** — causes drowsiness |
| Claritin (loratadine) | Likely yes (if no side effects) |
| Allegra (fexofenadine) | Likely yes (if no side effects) |

bogeyman.message: If a question names a medication and asks if the pilot can fly, determine whether it's SEDATING. Benadryl = NO. Claritin = likely YES (if no side effects).

sections.title: Stress, Fatigue, and Hyperventilation
sections.content:
## Stress Effects

| Type | Effect |
|---|---|
| **Acute stress** | Initial response can enhance performance, but quickly degrades it if intense or prolonged |
| **Chronic stress** | Steadily erodes judgment, situational awareness, and decision-making |

## Fatigue

Fatigue directly attacks situational awareness and ADM.

| Type | Recovery |
|---|---|
| Acute fatigue | Can be recovered with rest |
| Chronic fatigue | Cannot be fixed with one good night of sleep — takes multiple nights |

**"I'll drink more coffee"** is never the correct answer to fatigue. The only real countermeasure is adequate rest.

## Hyperventilation

**Cause:** Rapid or deep breathing removes too much CO₂ from the blood.

**Symptoms:**
- Dizziness
- Tingling in lips and fingers
- Lightheadedness
- Impaired judgment

**Treatment:**
1. **Slow your breathing** deliberately
2. Breathe into a paper bag (rebreathes CO₂)
3. Symptoms subside within minutes

bogeyman.message: Hyperventilation treatment: SLOW the breathing rate. The paper bag method works by increasing CO₂ levels back to normal.

sections.title: Dehydration and Heatstroke
sections.content:
## Dehydration

**Key Fact:** By the time you feel thirsty, you've already lost enough fluid to affect your judgment.

**Prevention:** Drink water *before* you're thirsty — at least one pint per hour during moderate outdoor work.

**Effect on Remote Pilots:** Dehydration affects **mental** performance (decision-making, situational awareness), not just physical comfort.

## Heatstroke

Heatstroke is a life-threatening emergency where the body can no longer regulate its temperature.

**Symptoms:**
- Extreme confusion
- Hot/dry skin
- Potential loss of consciousness

**Response:**
1. Move the person to shade
2. Cool them immediately
3. Call 911

sections.title: Vision and the Eye
sections.content:
## Types of Vision

| Type | When Used | Characteristics |
|---|---|---|
| Photopic (daylight) | Day operations | Cone cells provide sharp, color vision |
| Scotopic (night) | Night operations | Rod cells provide black-and-white vision with high sensitivity but poor detail |

## The Blind Spot

Where the optic nerve connects to the retina — approximately **15° from center**.

No photoreceptors at this point. Small objects can disappear if they fall directly in this area.

## Empty-Field Myopia

When looking at a featureless sky (no depth cues), your eyes naturally focus at a resting distance of about **3–6 feet**.

Distant aircraft become invisible.

**Prevention:** Regularly refocus on distant objects.

## Scanning Technique

Divide the sky into sectors and scan each for 1–2 seconds.

Small, systematic eye movements are more effective than large sweeping glances.

sections.title: Night Physiology
sections.content:
## Dark Adaptation

Your eyes need **20–30 minutes** to fully adapt to darkness.

During this time, avoid bright lights — especially white light.

If you're exposed to bright light after adapting, you must start the adaptation process over.

## Cockpit/Ground Station Lighting

Use **dim red light** for reading instruments and charts at night.

- Red light **preserves** dark adaptation
- White light **destroys** it

## Off-Center Viewing

At night, look slightly to the side of objects (**10–20°**) rather than directly at them.

Rod cells (used in dim light) are more concentrated in the peripheral retina, making peripheral vision more effective in darkness.

bogeyman.message: Dark adaptation takes 20-30 minutes. Use RED light at night to preserve it — white light destroys dark adaptation. Use OFF-CENTER viewing for better night vision.

sections.title: Night Illusions
sections.content:
## Common Night Illusions

### Autokinesis

Staring at a single stationary light against a dark background for more than a few seconds causes it to **appear to move**.

**Prevention:** Don't fixate on single lights — keep your eyes scanning.

### False Horizon

Ground lights can be confused with stars, creating a false sense of what's level.

This can cause disorientation, especially over dark terrain with scattered lights.

### Black Hole Approach

Approaching a landing zone over dark, featureless terrain (water, desert) distorts your perception of the approach angle.

Can lead to dangerous maneuvering.

### Featureless Terrain Illusion

Over flat, uniform surfaces (water, snow, desert), it's extremely difficult to judge altitude and distance.

## Exam Identification

| Description | Illusion |
|---|---|
| Stationary light appears to move | **Autokinesis** |
| Confusion between ground lights and stars | **False horizon** |

bogeyman.message: AUTOKINESIS = stationary light appears to move. Happens when you stare at a single light for several seconds at night. Keep scanning to prevent it!

lessons.title: Maintenance and Inspection
objectives: Describe preflight inspection requirements
Identify who may perform sUAS maintenance
Explain night preflight requirements
Understand Declaration of Compliance for operations over people

sections.title: Basic Maintenance
sections.content:
## What is Routine sUAS Maintenance?

Routine maintenance includes:
- Propeller inspection and replacement
- Motor cleaning
- Battery servicing
- Firmware updates
- Sensor calibration

## Key Difference from Manned Aircraft

**Unlike manned aircraft, sUAS maintenance does not require an A&P (Airframe & Powerplant) mechanic.**

**Any competent person** — including the owner/operator — can perform all maintenance.

This is the single biggest difference from manned aircraft maintenance.

## Techniques to Mitigate Mechanical Failures

| Component | Best Practice |
|---|---|
| Battery | Monitor voltage throughout flight; track cycle count; replace aging batteries |
| Propellers | Inspect before every flight; replace per manufacturer schedule (typically 50–100 flight hours) |
| Motors | Check for debris, corrosion, smooth bearing operation |
| Firmware | Keep current; always test after updating |

bogeyman.message: Any competent person can maintain an sUAS — NO A&P mechanic certificate required. This is the biggest difference from manned aircraft maintenance!

sections.title: Preflight Inspection
sections.content:
## Regulatory Requirement

14 CFR 107.49 requires the Remote PIC to ensure the sUAS is in a **condition for safe operation**.

## Preflight Inspection Checklist

### Structure
- Check for cracks, loose fasteners, damage to arms/fuselage
- Verify antenna condition
- Confirm payload security

### Propellers and Motors
- Look for chips, cracks, bends in propellers
- Spin motors briefly to check for smooth operation
- **Any damaged propeller = do not fly**

### Battery
- Verify adequate charge for the mission
- Check for swelling, damage, or leakage
- Ensure contacts are clean and secure

### Electronics
- Power all systems and verify no error messages
- Test gimbal/camera, telemetry display, receiver status

### Compass
- Calibrate before every flight per manufacturer recommendations
- Calibrate at the launch site, away from metal structures, power lines, vehicles

### GPS
- Verify satellite lock (typically 8+ satellites)
- Do not launch until position is stable

### Control Link
- Confirm transmitter is bound
- Verify sticks respond correctly
- Check failsafe settings

sections.title: Record Keeping
sections.content:
## Record Keeping Requirements

While Part 107 does not **specifically mandate** flight logs or maintenance logs, the FAA can request records upon inspection.

Maintaining them demonstrates professionalism and due diligence.

## Recommended Records

### Flight Log
- Date, time, location
- PIC name
- Duration
- Mission summary
- Issues encountered

### Maintenance Log
- Date
- Work performed
- Components replaced
- Who performed the work

### Battery Log
- Battery ID
- Charge cycle count
- Problems noted
- Replacement date

## Who May Perform Maintenance?

**Any competent person** can maintain an sUAS.

No A&P mechanic certificate is required.

The owner/operator can perform all maintenance tasks — from propeller replacement to motor swaps to firmware updates.

Manufacturer recommendations should be followed but are not legally binding unless referenced in a regulation.

bogeyman.message: Record keeping is RECOMMENDED best practice, not strictly required. But the FAA CAN request records, and having them shows compliance!

sections.title: Night Preflight Requirements
sections.content:
## Additional Night Preflight Checks

In addition to the standard preflight, night operations require:

### Anti-Collision Light Test

Verify the light is:
- **Functional**
- **Visible for 3 statute miles**

This is a **regulatory requirement**, not a suggestion.

### Light Battery Check

If the anti-collision light has its own battery, verify adequate charge for the entire mission.

### Strobe Pattern Verification

Confirm the flash pattern is correct and visible from all directions.

## Intensity Reduction

The anti-collision light intensity may be reduced if the Remote PIC determines full brightness would compromise safety — but it must still be visible for 3 statute miles.

bogeyman.message: Anti-collision lights must be visible for at least 3 STATUTE MILES during night operations. This must be verified during preflight!

sections.title: Declaration of Compliance
sections.content:
## What is a Declaration of Compliance (DoC)?

A Declaration of Compliance is documentation from the **manufacturer** certifying that a specific sUAS model meets the safety requirements for **Category 2 or Category 3 operations over people** under Part 107 Subpart D.

## Key Facts

| Fact | Detail |
|---|---|
| Who issues it? | The **manufacturer** (not the pilot) |
| What's required? | The DoC must be **FAA-accepted** (not just a manufacturer claim) |
| When needed? | Before conducting Cat 2 or Cat 3 operations over people |
| Without DoC? | You **cannot** operate over non-participants |

## Operations Over People Categories

| Category | Requirements |
|---|---|
| Category 1 | Under 0.55 lbs, no exposed rotating parts |
| Category 2 | FAA-accepted DoC required |
| Category 3 | FAA-accepted DoC required, additional operational restrictions |
| Category 4 | FAA airworthiness certificate required |

bogeyman.message: If a question asks what's needed before operating a Category 2 or 3 sUAS over people, the answer includes a manufacturer's Declaration of Compliance ACCEPTED by the FAA!
